newsitem.title: USA: WTO 'admission fee' must be fair - China's Wu.
newsitem.headline: WTO 'admission fee' must be fair - China's Wu.

text.p: Trade Minister Wu Yi said China was ready to be flexible in negotiations to join the World Trade Organization but warned Friday if "our admission fee is too high, we cannot afford it."
Wu said China should be admitted under the more lenient rules offered to developing nations.
U.S. Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor, appearing at a news conference with Wu, said China should join on a basis that takes into account its large economy.
"We are prepared to show greater flexibility" in upcoming negotiations on WTO accession, Wu said, adding China had no timetable for when it would join WTO.
"China needs to join the WTO and the WTO needs China," Wu said, describing China as the 11th largest trading nation.
Wu also criticized the U.S. position on Chinese textile exports. The United States has expressed concern that some goods were being transshipped through other nations as a way to evade import limits.
It was a "big shortcoming" and "unfair" to exclude China from WTO, Wu said, adding Beijing was ready to pay an "admission fee."
But, she said, WTO membership "must be in line with our economic development. If the request for our admission fee is too high, we cannot afford it. I do not have so much money in my pocket."
One day ago, Acting U.S. Trade Representative Charlene Barchevsky said China failed to show "a serious interest" in joining WTO and was "treading water" on economic reform.
Washington wants China to undertake a number of reforms to open its markets to imported goods as a condition for joining WTO.
"Whether or when China joins WTO, China will not stop its reform and opening-up policy," Wu said.
China is the fifth largest U.S. trade partner and ranks second to Japan in running a massive trade surplus in dealings with the United States.
As part of two days of trade meetings, the United States announced $495 million in loan guarantees for sales of U.S. aircraft and three contracts for software to Chinese agencies.
